text:
In seventh grade I looked through a
microscope for the first time and I saw

a Paramecium swimming around and I was
just fascinated I never wanted to move

from a microscope again that was where I
wanted to spend my life I'm Jo

Handelsman I'm a microbiologist it was
just like that look huh how does that

fit together and it was clearly girl
science girls can't do that when you ask

kids to draw scientists most will draw
the same image white bald guy with a

pointy beard little glasses and a white
lab coat and then when I was in 10th

grade I had a biology teacher mr. post
Leone and he convinced me that I could

do science as a girl and finally when I
got to graduate school I started seeing

role models in science women who had
done what I wanted to do they'd become

biologists professors they did research
and realized those two things can go

together you can be female and you can
be a science professor you don't have to
look like those guys

microbiome is a community of
microorganisms associated with some

environment from the ocean to the soil
to the human gut and it's rapidly

evolving science we are beginning to
understand the roles that they play in

regulating our own health and our immune
systems much of chronic disease is now

being associated with changes in our
microbiomes obesity heart disease asthma

the list is very extensive if we can
control those microbial communities we
can take enormous advantage of them I

was one of the science advisors for
President Obama during the last three

years of his administration welcome to
the White House Science Fair he is a

wonderful fan of science this stuff's
really cool it was the high point of his

day having a discussion about
initiatives to change American science

precision medicine is a science trying
to figure out what's different between

individual people that makes one person
respond to a treatment and another
person not

President Obama was personally committed
to it tonight I'm launching a new

precision medicine initiative he was
very excited about making this front and

center of the future of American
medicine the right treatment at the

right time a bill was passed that had
about four point eight billion dollars

would you do this I think it's one of
our most successful initiatives from my
time at the White House

I was in the habit of giving President
Obama stuff microbes and these were

little miniature microorganisms that
represented in real microbes the very

first one I gave him was of a
streptococcus flesh-eating bacteria one

of the scientists was just totally
baffled what are you gonna do with it

little coy it was quite an experience to
work with him at one of the world's

problems was that antibiotics that we
have no longer worked with many of our

diseases but industry has kind of lost
interest we're trying to rebuild that

interest soil bacteria are these
prolific producers of antibiotic

activity about 75% of the antibiotics in
current use are from soil bacteria

and there's some pretty good evidence
that bacteria are producing antibiotics

for sending messages to each other and
so we are just co-opting something that

the bacteria are making to use as drugs
for our own purposes

small world is something that I started
in 2012 to teach science through solving

the worlds of problems with young bright
scientists in the classroom they would

learn about science through culturing
bacteria from soil for production of

antibiotics it's been a really
extraordinary process to see all of the

students and their instructors
passionate about antibiotic discovery
from soil

above all failure is okay there are
messages that are sent in science about

failure that just shouldn't be sent
failure is a part of science it doesn't

mean you're not good at it it doesn't
mean to stop it just means to go back

and do it again I so often hear students
say oh I'm not a science person I always

thought I was just sort of unfit for
science and I never knew why and I'm

sure part of it was just not seeing
people who looked like me in science

we all bring these stereotypes and
prejudices to our decisions about people

and it also means that we can all undo
that

the future of science is so much
brighter and stronger because there are

more women and minorities and people
with lots of different backgrounds but
it could be even stronger
